newsitem.title: ITALY: Italy union signals some opening to pension reform.
newsitem.headline: Italy union signals some opening to pension reform.

text.p: Sergio Cofferati, leader of Italy's biggest trades union, CGIL, said he was ready to discuss some possible reforms to the country's pension system if necessary.

Cofferati, who has made a prior meeting with the government on its three-year economic plan (DPEF) conditional on any reform talks, said he believed that partial pension reforms implemented in 1995 were still valid today.
Those changes to the country's generous and creaking pensions system introduced a graduated increase in the pensionable age and the opening up of a pay-as-you-go contributions system.
"We think the 1995 reform is still effective today," Cofferati told the annual congress of the CISL trades union.
"We demand a review of if and how to implement new action on pensions...but our union will not avoid any eventual new requirements," he said.

He said the results of such a review would be "binding on all involved," adding that "to demand even just one small sacrifice of the weakest one must show that one is capable of also asking the same of the strongest."
"Our challenge to the government is exactly this and we will be tackling the issue in the coming days," he added.

Prime Minister Romano Prodi's government intends to approve the DPEF document, which sets economic targets for the next three years as well as outlines of planned welfare reform, by the end of next week.
He has already announced plans for meetings with unions, employers and majority parties to discuss the document.
Cofferati said, "we have the right to demand a committed discussion first on the DPEF and then detailed talks on social welfare.
"Welfare reform is in our interest, but the premise must be to guarantee fairness and balance," he added. -- Rome newsroom +396 6782501
